text: The rest of BBS life was sort of like Twitter, except imagine if Twitter only had like, 100 people, and they could only comment once a day because that's the only time they could manage to log on. Debates would go on and on and on...

text: The BBS was really popular -- had to dial for hours in the middle of the night to have any chance of logging on. And everybody wanted to play that game. People were really mad at me. Convinced I was cheating. The operator weighed in and told people I wasn't.

text:
Couple of vintage John Dingell quotes:

“People don’t judge you whether you get a bill,” he told me. “They judge you on what you get done.”

He told his staff: “You go find the facts. We will cook the politics to suit the facts.”
author: StevenTDennis

text: Dingell came from a time when lawmakers spent a lot more time hanging out together, and across party lines. He lamented the polarized era that he told me came in with Gingrich, who he said warped the rules.
author: StevenTDennis

text: Republicans likes working with John Dingell; he once told Nancy Pelosi when they differed on energy legislation strategy that he wouldn’t deliver a Democratic bill but he would deliver a Democratic accomplishment. He was focused on getting a result.
author: StevenTDennis

text:
I remember sitting down with John Dingell in his office; he told me stories about witnessing FDR’s Day of Infamy speech as a House page, of heading to WWII at age 18 a few years later, trapping bears, and his own art of the deal.
He was both larger than life and down to earth.
author: StevenTDennis

text: John Dingell kept the gavel used to preside over the Medicare debate in 1965 for decades; he spent decades after that trying to extend health coverage to everyone else. When ACA first passed House, Ds lined up with the tome so he could sign it. And he brought his gavel.
